case_vignette: a 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh. she initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past weeks. her temperature is 36.7°c (98°f), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm hg. physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule. when the skin lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inwards. a photograph of the lesion is shown.
question: which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painless skin lesion on my right thigh that has slowly grown larger over the past month.
Has the lesion changed in color or bled at any point?
No, it has not changed in color or bled.

I don't have any personal or family history of skin cancer.

No, there are no changes in sensation like numbness or tingling over the lesion.

No, I have not had any recent exposure to chemicals, persistent irritation, or trauma to that area of skin.
How old are you and what is your gender?
I am a 38-year-old woman.
Is the lesion raised or flush with the skin, and does it have a smooth or rough texture?
The lesion is raised and has a smooth texture.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatofibroma
